title: A bird’s eye view of the beauty around us
story: WE may often take for granted the stunning scenery on our doorstep but, with the help of Up and Above Aerial Media, we are reminded of the beauty that surrounds us.This week and next week we will be running a series of highly impressive birdrsquos eye view images of ious towns and villages across the district.Renowned for its picturesque quality, the district is blessed with an abundance of natural beauty and this weekrsquos images show Newcastle, Castlewellan, Downpatrick, Killyleagh, Ardglass and Killough, all from an unusual angle..prettyPhoto

title: Brazil and the Downpatrick Youth League
story: ALMOST  years ago Brazilian magic found its way into the Downpatrick Youth Football League.Mexico , arguably the greatest World Cup of all time, was won by Brazil, was won by Brazil, without doubt the greatest international team of all time.Carlos Alberto, Gerson, Tostao, Jairzinho, Felix the goalkeeper and the incomparable Pele, names that trip of the tongue.Another wearing the famed yellow shirt was the left midfielder Rivelino, famed for his dribbling skills and bullet-like shot.In the wake of the World Cup, David Keating and a group of friends decided to enter a team in the Downpatrick Youth League.They needed a manager and Davidrsquos brother, Austin, offered to take the role. The next job was to find a team name.Thoughts turned to Brazil and Rivelino.His club was Corinthians of Sao Paulo. The name stuck and soon there would be Corinthians of the Downpatrick Youth League.ldquoWe had a couple of good seasons, nothing special, but around  Austin got a squad of very good footballers together, David recalls.Each Saturday morning Austin took his big Ford Corsair out to Saul and Raholp to collect some boys, including Pat lsquoSkipperrsquo McMullan, Sean McMullan, Lorny Murphy and Noel Denvir.These joined a group of players from Crossgar, such as Mel and Con McCarthy, Leo Casement, Dan McHugh, Gregory Bell, lsquoChippyrsquo Bell and lsquoBootsiersquo Madine.Though Austin had an excess of players and it was hard to give everyone a game, the Crossgar boys encouraged him to sign a number of Killyleagh lads and so Jute Sullivan, Kevin Nelson and Chris Hagan joined up. They were a very talented forward line and team.Corinthiansrsquo main rivals were Panathinaikos, managed by Pat McKinney.At the end of the season Austin won the leaguersquos Manager of the Year award, for which he was very proud.He went on to be involved with Downpatrick Rec and was club chairman when they won the Steel and Sons Cup.Many of the Corinthians players went on to play for local teams in the Amateur League and Newcastle League, and also played Gaelic football.Corinthians may no longer exist, but they are still fondly remembered by those who can recall the early days of the Downpatrick Youth League and were fired up by the wizards of Brazil..prettyPhoto

title: Centre set up as new community support hub
story: A NEW community co-ordination hub to deliver essential supplies to vulnerable residents across the district has been set up at the Down Leisure Centre.The Market Street facility has been transformed into a new distribution centre to help meet the needs of people who have been confined to home as part of the governmentrsquos lockdown measures.And with restrictions on movement set to remain in place for the next few weeks, the new community hub will have an increasingly important role to play.Local council officials have been working in partnership with their colleagues across local government, health trusts and the Department for Communities to set up the hub.The Down Leisure Centre has been transformed into a processing centre to organise deliveries, with other sites currently being identied should they be required.When fully operational, over  leisure centre staff have been redeployed to work across all sites and alongside others from across the organisation to help operate a lsquovirtualrsquo hub to coordinate the response.Staff are working in split shts, while observing social distancing and other safety protocols.The new service covers the councilrsquos seven even district electoral areas with deliveries focusing on food supplies.In addition, a COVID- community helpline is already operational, with those in vulnerable groups seeking support can make contact between am and pm, seven days a week, with the helpline managed by Advice NI who are processing calls from across Northern Ireland.The freephone number is   , while the email is covid@adviceni.net. Contact can also be made by texting ACTION to .All calls that are relevant to the councilrsquos community co-ordination hub will be passed on to the local authority for action, including referrals from the South Eastern and Southern health trusts.The Downpatrick-based County Down Rural Community Network, the Confederation of Community Groups in Newry and Community Advice Newry Mourne and Down are acting as lead organisations for the community groups involved in this response.Council chairman Charlie Casey is encouraging those in vulnerable groups needing help to contact the freephone helpline.ldquoFrom the outset of our coronavirus response, we wanted to make sure we could reach those in the district who might need our help the most, he explained.ldquoThis is a very dficult time for all of us and we want to make sure that our most vulnerable residents have access to essential supplies. No one should feel they are on their own so please donrsquot hesitate to get in touch on   you need assistance.The council chairman thanked everyone involved in getting the new coordination hub up and running, explaining that he is aware of the hard work going on behind the scenes over the past week.More information on the COVID- Community Helpline is available at the NI Direct website https:www.nidirect.gov.uk articles coronavirus-covid--advice-vulnerable-people..prettyPhoto

title: Down camogie players helping health workers
story: THE Down camogie team is doing its bit to help frontline workers in the battle against coronavirus.Big-hearted members of the team have donated their first sets of scrubs to the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald.The package was delivered by defender Aoe Savage, from Ballygalget, who is a dietitian in the hospital.The camogs responded to the outbreak of Covid- and the shutdown of all sport by coming up with an activity that would both keep the team active and working towards a common goal as well as fund-raising for a deserving cause.Since March  they have been doing inidual runs hoping that the whole  will be able to run a total of ,km by April .At the same time they have been raising much-needed funds for frontline workers and local homeless charities in the county during the coronavirus emergency.Two-and-a half weeks in and the girls are half-way to their target distance and have raised pound,, which is pretty impressive given that as many as eight players on the  are frontline workers mdash a fact that has sometimes placed restrictions on their involvement.Aoe gives a breakdown of where her team-mates work.ldquoCaoimhe Byrne is a nurse here in the Ulster Hospital and Frances Toner is a clerical officer here as well.ldquoMy sister Alannah is an assistant psychologist in Whiteabbey Hospital, Aoe Keown is a physiotherapist in Daisy Hill in Newry and DeeMcCabe is a nurse in the Royal.ldquoThen Danielle Harrison is an occupational therapist and Maria McNally is a dental nurse.ldquoThankfully none of us have had to isolate, although some have had to adjust living arrangements so that they are not in contact with vulnerable relations, she explains.ldquoThe fund-raiser has given everyone a focus and been good for team morale, but it has been challenging at times to get the mileage done.Aoe is one of three sisters currently in the Down .As well as Alannah, Queenrsquos student Blaacutenaid had just ed to action in the last league game against Carlow on March  following a series of injuries that had side-lined her for the past six months.There are a further two sisters, Deirbhile who, alongside Aoe, won an All-Ireland Junior medal with Down in  and under  player Saerlaith.Aoe has her four siblings all lined up for a special assignment in July when she is due to marry Down hurler and Ulster GAA hurling development officer Danny Toner, also from Ballygalget.ldquoWe are getting a little nervous about the wedding. At the moment all the plans are in place for it to go ahead on the scheduled date. But we cannot be certain what is ahead.ldquoWe had all planned to avoid camogie and hurling hot-spots. Butsporting action resumes there might now be games on the day.ldquoIf we are still on lock-down, then we have to chase another date, avoid hurling and camogie fixtures of course.ldquoIrsquom sure it will all work out some way or other.ldquoThere are many more serious issues going on around us at the moment and that is why it was important for us young and healthy Down players to find something useful to do to alleviate the situation for the health workers and the homeless.If you wish to contribute to the Down camogie fund-raiser, follow the link https:www.gofundme f support-front-line-workers teamInviteTXYrtymUlOOSpxwLVEmMuxDlBVbXlDyVvGPGywEBaOfypKdBcANpxlL.prettyPhoto

title: Easter eggs delight for ambulance staff
story: AMBULANCE Service staff at the frontline of the emergency response to the coronavirus pandemic have been presented with some Easter cheer by the Downpatrick and Co Down Railway.The heritage railway mdash which has been forced to close as a result of the virus mdash has donated nearly  Easter eggs to hard-working paramedics.Railway chairman Robert Gardiner said Good Friday usually heralded the eve of the Easter bunny visits to the facility to distribute sumptuous eggs.Robert said that with no explanation needed why the bunny was absent this year, rather than waste all the eggs, officials thought they would find good homes for them.They chose some people who may not get a chance to be with their family and friends and putting themselves literally at the frontline at this worrying time.ldquoSome Recorder readers might recognise one of the faces of the ambulance crew from our social media posts, Robert explained.ldquoJohnny McKillen is a regular face on our operating days in his full DCDR unorm, but his day job is as a paramedic with the Ambulance Service based at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast. We have been very aware through him of the challenges facing ambulance staff as the first responders during the coronavirus crisis.Last week, volunteers visited ambulance stations in Belfast and Downpatrick to surprise crews with literally hundreds of Easter eggs.Robert added: ldquoWe have been assured that the eggs will be distributed around the ious ambulance stations and not all end up in Johnnyrsquos house.ldquoWe still have around  eggs available for any good cause, originally earmarked for organisations or groups working with children finding it tough during self-isolation.ldquoWe would ask anyone involved with such a group tous an email or PM via our facebook page @downrail..prettyPhoto

title: Food parcels for senior citizens in Ballynahinch
story: NINETY parcels of free meat was distributed to senior citizens in Ballynahinch last week to help them during the coronavirus lockdown.The welcome gesture was paid by the Community Foundation and the County Down Rural Community Network.Each recipient received fresh chops, mince meat and steak pieces in what currently is a one-off donation.Volunteers from Ballynahinch Community Networkhanded out the parcels with the meat supplied by Poolersquos Butchers in the town.Ballynahinch Community Network vice-chairman Richard Orme said: ldquoI would just like to praise everyonersquos spirit at this hard time and for all the help our group and volunteers and of course our funders for their kind help.ldquoWe are just doing our bit to help our own community in time of need so thank you all. Please take care and stay safe everyone.BCC members have been very active recently in collecting food donations and delivering food packages on behalf of Ballynahinch Food Bank, which is run from Ballynahinch First Presbyterian Church.The food bank also received pound worth of food donated by the staff of Lidl in Ballynahinch..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C April 15%2C 1980
story: DRUMANESS mdash A group of Drumaness residents have formed a committee to help put a businessman back on his feet following an incredible series of mishaps.A fire last week destroyed Mr Gerry Ricersquos business in the village and damaged the pre-fab accommodation in which he has been living with his we and ten children. It is the latest jinx in a long series of mishaps which have bedevilled the garage proprietor.The Rice family moved to Drumaness in what seemed the final chapter in a long running wrangle over a smoke problem at their home in Carlisle Park, Ballynahinch.The fire destroyed almost everything and it was in response to the ldquoraw deal which Mr Rice was getting that the Drumaness committee was formed.The Drumaness Community Action Committee is only eight-strong, but a spokesman pointed out that they had the backing of the whole community.A collection was taken around the Drumaness district last week and raised more than pound for Mr Rice. Since then donations have been pouring in and already another pound has been collected.The spokesman added: ldquoWe think he [Mr Rice] is getting a raw deal and we are determined to do something about it.BALLYNAHINCH mdash Work is well underway on a pound, environmental improvement scheme for Ballynahinch Square.The scheme, which will give the much-maligned square a major facelt, has been brought about after much pressure from the local chamber of commerce.The chamber has been pushing for the resurfacing of the square for over a decade, but the breakthrough didnrsquot occur until late last year when negotiations between the owners, the Ker Estate, and the Department of the Environment were finally completed.The scheme will entail the resurfacing of the square, the planting of shrubs, the building of a lsquositting wallrsquo and the re-use of flower boxes. It is expected to be completed within several months.NEWCASTLE mdash The Northern Ireland Tourist Board is to pump pound, into Newcastlersquos Harry Ferguson Festival this summer.Newcastle Town Committee, organisers of the festival, were pleased to hear of the Boardrsquos agreement to sponsor entertainment at a cost of pound, when they met last week.More than half of this amount, which was requested by the Town Committee, will go towards bandstand entertainment.However, the committee also discussed a reply from Down District Council regarding pound, assistance towards the festival. They noted with regret that the council was again unable to give them any support.The committee agreed there was great interest in the town on their ambitious plans, particularly the initiative to build a replica of the Ferguson monoplane, and it was agreed that an appeal for funds to local businesses, hotels and guest houses would have to be made in the near future.Mr Fergusonrsquos daughter will be coming to Newcastle on July and it is hoped she will attend the Miss Newcastle ball, which will be held in the Slieve Donard Hotel that night, and the festival parade the following day.DOWNPATRICK mdash A call has been made this week for the public to help stamp out vandalism in the Downpatrick area.It comes from Downpatrick councillor, Mr Cecil Maxwell, who felt he had to speak out after three incidents at Downpatrick Cathedral last week when excrement was littered around the building.ldquoIt is sad that a holy place is vandalised, especially in Holy Week, he said. ldquoThe time has come for the general public to stop this sheer vandalism.Appealing for more co-operation from the public with the police, Mr Maxwell pointed out that other churches and schools in the area had also suffered severely at the hands of vandals.CROSSGAR mdash Crossgar Choral Societyrsquos ninth annual concert, Sing A Rainbow, will be presented next Tuesday and Wednesday in the War Memorial Hall, Crossgar.Such is the standard of this musical event that the society plays to full houses every year and there is no doubt that this yearrsquos production will be correspondingly attended. Annually, each new show is taken on tour for the benefit of ious charitiesOn April  the show will be performed in Killyleagh High School in aid of Glendhu Childrenrsquos Home and on May  in the Downshire Hospital, Downpatrick, in aid of the hydrotherapy pool at Knockevin School.Angela Bradley is the choreographer and producer, Bertie Rourke is the musical director and Stella King is the accompanist. Frank Bradley takes care o the lighting and David Eynon is the stage manager for this happy and hard working crew.SAINTFIELD mdash Mrs Margaret Atkins, we of the Secretary of State, Mr Humphrey Atkins, visited one of Northern Irelandrsquos largest mushroom factories in Saintfield on Monday.Mr Robert McBriar and Mr Eric Patterson, joint owners of Overdale Mushrooms, told Mrs Atkins that the business, which was set up over  years ago as a glasshouse nursery, later changed to mushroom production and now employs  people.Mrs Atkins was shown over the facilities and saw the ious stages in mushroom production.ARDGLASS mdash Plans are at an advanced stage for this yearrsquos Ardglass Herring Festival, which will take place early in August. Although the festival has been shortened to five days, the organisers have drafted a programme as big as last year and only the final details remain to be worked out.On the opening day, Tuesday, August , Guinness are sponsoring a superstars event and the organisers have managed to attract local and national stars. There will also be a quiz and a dance to the popular Luv Bug.Wednesday, Thursday and Friday mornings are given over to childrenrsquos events. Adults events on Wednesday include a GAA programme and on Thursday there is a whelk-eating competition and a yard of ale drinking competition. Fridayrsquos events include a pram race grand prix around the town with substantial prize money.Saturday is the day for the sportsmen and outdoor events, beginning with a clay pigeon shoot at the harbour and ending with a soccer programme including Ardglass Old Crocks versus an Irish international Old Crocks.These are only a few of the many events lined up by the organising committee.BALLYGOWAN mdash The village of Ballygowan reverberated to the sound of pipes and drums on Saturday. The occasion was the mini pipe band contest organised by Saintfield Pipe Band, which attracted almost  pipers and drummers.The annual Easter feast of piping is the curtain raiser too the start of the full contest season, with the two adjudicators from Scotland commenting on the big turnout.A new trophy, to be competed for in Grade , was presented by Mr David Hunter, a former member of the Saintfield band who was home on vacation from Canada. Mr Eddie McVeigh, from Ballynahinch, president of the Royal Scottish Pipe Bands Association, later congratulated the pipe majors on their work in preparing for the event.BALLYWARD mdash A Ballyward man, who has almost  years of management experience abroad, is to head up one of Northern Irelandrsquos newest industries.Mr Mike Gordon is the chief executive of American Monitor International, a joint venture between the parent company based in Indianapolis and the Northern Ireland Development Agency.The American Monitor Company manufactures diagnostic equipment for hospital and industrial use and the new company based in Belfast will be responsible for production and marketing for Europe.Mr Gordon, who is , is an honours graduate in electronics from Queenrsquos University, Belfast, has wide experience of manufacturing processes in ious parts of the world. His career spans training with politan Vickersand the Bristol Aircraft Company in Great Britain, as well as Amalgamated Wireless Australasia, the largest electronics company in the southern hemisphere, and Algeriarsquos National Oil Company..prettyPhoto

title: Gridlock
story: THEof motorsport action to Bishopscourt racing circuit has been ruled out until August the earliest owing to the coronavirus pandemic.Circuit officials have been forced to a cancel a number of meetings, which would normally provide a major boost to the local economy.The first casualty is this Saturdayrsquos Enkalon Trophy meetingmdash one of the biggest of the year and which includes round of the Ulster Superbike Championship.Also cancelled is a touring car meeting scheduled for May -, a karting event on June  and a big charity meeting in aid of Air Ambulance Northern Ireland the following day.The Donny Robinson Memorial meeting in July, which includes another round of the Ulster Superbike Championship, has also been called off.A meeting for classic motorbikes, due to take place in August, is still on, but whether it actually goes ahead is doubtful.The Easter weekend usually brings out motorbike fans in their thousands. Another victim of the pandemic is Easter Mondayrsquos Ulster Superbike Championship meeting at Kirkistown.Bishopscourt circuit manager Roy Biggerstaff said: ldquoIt terribly disappointing. Wersquove already had to cancel the Temple  meeting, which was due to take place on March , and included the first round of the Ulster Superbike Championship.ldquoThe only motorsport we have had here this year is a rally stages event on March . Since then we have been completely shut down.ldquoCoronavirus is having a big impact on motorsport here at Bishopscourt and on the local economy. Motorsport brings major economic benefits, particularly for bars, restaurants, bed and breakfast accommodation providers and shops.ldquoThe Enkalon Trophy is usually one of best supported meetings of the year and the charity meeting for the Air Ambulance was going to be massive.ldquoI have been involved in motorsport for a long time and this is as bad as I can remember. My phone hasnrsquot stopped with people calling and wanting to know what is going on.However, Mr Biggerstaff said sport was much less important than the need to safeguard public health and save lives.ldquoThe health and welfare of the public is the major concern right now. Our hands are tied until the coronavirus pandemic dies down and then we will take our guidance from the Motorcycle Union of Ireland Ulster Centre, which is our governing body.He added: ldquoI hope motorsport fans and the public in general understand the situation and that everyone is trying to their best. When this pandemic ends we will come back bigger and stronger..prettyPhoto

title: I THOUGHT ‘THIS IS IT’
story: A CROSSGAR man has recovered after his ldquohorric near-death fight against COVID-.Seamus Bell was treated in hospital for double pneumonia in his lungs after testing positive for the deadly virus eight days ago.Separated from his fianceacutee, Mr Bell thought he would not recover from the disease which left him unable to talk and struggling to breathe.The  year-old is now at home in quarantine after being released from hospital on Easter Sunday.Mr Bell has praised all the medical staff at the Mater Hospital and the City Hospital in Belfast for helping him in his recovery.However, he said that it was the calm reassurance of another Crossgar man, respiratory nurse specialist David Moore at the Mater, who really helped him cope with some of the darker moments in his time in hospital.Highlighting the dficulty in diagnosing the disease and the unpredictability of it, Mr Bell told the Recorder that after feeling ill nearly three weeks ago, he made two  calls, spoke with four doctors, visited two hospitals and tested negative for COVID- in the Mater before it was finally confirmed three days later that he had the virus.ldquoWhen they came in to tell me, it was a massive shock, said Mr Bell. ldquoThen I got really scared and I texted my fianceacutee to say that I was frightened, I donrsquot know whatrsquos going to happen orIrsquom ever going to see you again.ldquoIt was horrendous, I was that scared. I thought lsquothis is itrsquo and I wasnrsquot coming out of here, so to speak to someone from home like David Moore, who knew some of my relatives, and to get that reassurance from him meant so much.ldquoHe came into to see me each day I was at the Mater and had to be suited in PPE every time he came. It was just horric.Mr Bell does not yet know where he picked up the virus, orhe passed it on to anyone . Thankfully, his fianceacutee, Bernie Henry, who shares a home with him, did not contract the virus as they were both committed to social distancing as soon as he felt unwell.He said: ldquoI work all over Northern Ireland in my job, meeting people face to face, so I could have picked it up anywhere, said Mr Bell.ldquoThe first thing I knew about it was when I came home from work on the Friday [nearly three weeks ago] feeling a bit faint and ice cold in my feet and hands. I started to have really bad headaches.ldquoTwo days later I rang the out of hours and was toldthe headaches didnrsquot get any better to go to Lagan Valley Hospital which I did. They told me go home and to self-isolate for  days which we did.Mr Bellrsquos headaches continued and after consulting his own GP he went to the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald where X-rays showed that his lungs were clear and he was sent home to continue his quarantine.Then, four days later, he called for paramedics again who prescribed him antibiotics but did not admit him to hospital.The day before he was admitted to the Mater Hospital ndash the gateway hospital for all suspected COVID patients ndash Mr Bell suffered an asthma attack and felt increasingly unable to breathe at home.His fianceacutee went on the NHS COVID app the next day to describe Mr Bellrsquos symptoms where it recorded a red warning and advised to ring .Mr Bell said: ldquoIf it wasnrsquot for that, God knows where I would have been today. It took it a week for it to really hit me but when it did, it was bad.He was treated initially with strong anti-biotics to open his airways and then with oxygen from a CPAP mask to get air into his lungs.Once medics believed that Mr Bell was on his way to recovery, he was transferred to the City Hospital.He said that he felt most vulnerable when he was in separate bay with five other patients with COVID-.ldquoItrsquos hard not to worry when you are in there as you see other people struggling, said Mr Bell.ldquoBecause of the pneumonia, it was a struggle to speak, for two days I couldnrsquot speak to anyone. Bernie was not allowed in to visit me so we would text. Once I told her how afraid I was and she rang the hospital and a doctor, who was a lovely guy, came in to speak to me and reassured me that the pneumonia had been stemmed.ldquoEveryone was so good, particularly Dr Suzy Guy and Dr Liggett, who first saw me at the Mater. You see these people on the television but little did I know that they would end up treating me please. I cannot thank them enough.Mr Bell advised local people: ldquoJust stay at home and do what the government is telling you to do. Some people arenrsquot and itrsquos up to all of us to try and beat this.He also had a message of hope for people who contract the virus: ldquoJust stay positive, have your faith as le can change very quickly when this hits you. You just donrsquot know how hard it will attack I was one of the lucky ones.ldquoI have a great network of friends from all religious backgrounds who prayed and supported me throughout my illness which Irsquom sincerely grateful.Mr Bell and his fianceacutee, who will marry in October, have only a few days of their quarantine at home left..prettyPhoto

title: Ian runs 107 miles to raise £3k for PIPS
story: DOWNPATRICK man Ian Hillsdon was not going to let a little thing like COVID- prevent him for raising money for his chosen charity.By running  miles ndash in his own back yard ndash the  year-old has raised nearly pound, for PIPS Downpatrick.Ian, from the Flying Horse, is chair of Down Triathlon Club and live-streamed his running on Facebook over a period of  hours and  minutes as he ran from one cone to another throughout last Friday night.His sporting challenge was viewed by more than , people on Facebook, with people supporting him and donating from as far as Australia, New Zealand and Texas.The father of one only took up running seriously a few years ago but quickly managed to complete runs at marathon distance and longer.He had planned to do an ultra-marathon on March  running  miles from Belfast to Dublin but the fear of coronavirus spread ended that aim when the event was cancelled.Ian, a civil servant, said: ldquoI briefly thought that maybe I could still do the run from my house on a two-mile loop going past the Downshire estate and try to do that  times.ldquoThen Boris Johnston called for a lockdown and advised going out once a day for exercise. I knew it wouldnrsquot be right to try it. I saw a few people running in their driveways so I looked out my back window and thought lsquoI wonderrsquo ldquoFrom my back door to my gate, is only four metres so I spaced the cones out by three metres apart. There are ,m in a mile so I roughly ran to each cone , times.Ian decided to test out his mathematics and ran five miles around the cones one evening before he started his long run last Friday morning.While Ian started out at am, he would jog and sometimes walk for an hour at a time and took short five minute breaks to eat or check in with his we Christine or seven year-old son Lucas.He explained: ldquoBecause itrsquos ultra-marathon running, you donrsquot have to be on the go the whole time. Itrsquos dferent than marathon running as you can run a bit and walk a bit.ldquoAs I was streaming it live on Facebook, I would also run past and give a thumbs-up to prove that it was live and I was doing it.ldquoAt one stage, it went down to about two people watching it in the middle of the night so I told them that I was going to walk a bit. The support on Facebook was brilliant as it kept me going.It was just after noon on Saturday that Ian was welcomed lsquohomersquo by his family and some several running friends who left him a well-earned pint of Guinness.Ian has raised money for PIPS Downpatrick before from his running, mostly in recognition of the great work that the charity does in the town and in memory of a friend who lost his le to suicide.A delighted Ian hopes to officially hand over the money to the charity once the lockdown is lted.However, people can still donate by visiting his Go Fund Me page at https:www.gofundme f wjmrbvdc.prettyPhoto

title: Joe shares message of hope after spending childhood in isolation
story: A CROSSGAR man, who contracted polio when he was a five month-old baby, has voiced a timely message of reassurance that the horrors of the coronavirus will pass.Seventy year-old Joe McVeigh could be described as a veteran of adversity.He was born in the Markets area of Belfast on Christmas Day , when polio was prevalent, particularly among children.Joe spent his first six years at Musgrave Park Hospital before being transferred to St Josephrsquos Hospital in Co Westmeath, where he remained until he was .He remembers very little of this hospital and recalls seeing his father just twice a year when he moved to Westmeath.He said: ldquoI was very little and I do remember hiding under the bed when teachers were coming around to do school lessons with us.Joe could not walk unaided and needed two callipers, which were connected to a back brace.St Josephrsquos was an orthopaedic hospital and people came and went. There were a few patients like Joe who were from Northern Ireland. They were there long term and kept in breathing apparatus known as an lsquoiron lungrsquo.Joersquos parents, Sam and Rosaleen, came to see him twice a year.ldquoThat was all they could afford, he said. ldquoMy father was a labourer. To visit me, he had to hire a car and stay overnight and go back up the next day.The years went by. It was his le.ldquoWhen I was , I got home for the summer holidays, Joe said.ldquoIt was very strange experience. I was nearly institutionalised. I remember having only hospital pyjamas and I hadnrsquot a stitch of clothing to my name.ldquoSomeone sewed me a pair of trousers made from flour sacks until my father took me out and bought me nice clothes.Joe says it took time to get used to living with his family but he was ldquospoiled rotten when he arrived home.ldquoIrsquod been used to sleeping in a ward with a lot of others mdash first the childrenrsquos ward, then the adultsrsquo ward. I had not been used to being around girls like my three sisters. I had to get to know my brother too.Joe married his we, Martina, in . He says they have been fortunate and are able to look after each other.In the current crisis, when he hears people talking about the problems of self isolation and seeing people rush to buy food, Joe wonders what the fuss is all about.ldquoI donrsquot understand or believe the panic, he said. ldquoMy message to people is that they will get through it.Joe is a member of the Northern Ireland Polio Fellowship. In recent years he became a champion player of boccia, which is similar to indoor bowls.Joe says that they have their own WhatsApp group to boost morale.ldquoTwenty-five of us took part in an online pub quiz last weekend. We keep each otherrsquos spirits up.ldquoOne of my friends which I met by accident when we were teenagers used to lie in the bed next to me in Musgrave Hospital. We are still good friends today.ldquoI got a message the other day that said, lsquoThere really is no problem with self-isolating. But how come one of my bags of rice contains , grains and the other has , rsquoldquoPeople who had polio had to work for years to reclaim their limbs and their movement. You didnrsquot just recover, stand up and walk away.Joersquos message for all those facing the horrors of the coronavirus is one of perseverance ndash from someone who has lived and faced hard times..prettyPhoto

title: Major boost for nursing home from Castlewellan Orangemen
story: NEWCASTLErsquoS River House residential home has been presented with a consignment of hand sanitiser from local Orangemen.The donation was made by Castlewellan District No  which comprises the lodges of Castlewellan, Newcastle, Bryansford, Maghera, Aughlisnafin, Ballywillwill and Dundrum, who mobilised their members to assist the local fight against COVID-.The Castlewellan District is concentrating its support efforts on locally based health care staff, including those who work in nursing and residential homes.As a key first step, lodge members have been able to purchase a quantity of hand sanitiser with the first batch distributed to the Newcastle residential home.In a separate initiative, members of Newcastle Temperance LOL No  have made a substantial donation to the townrsquos Pantry Foodbank to assist it in its important work within the community..prettyPhoto

title: Mum working from home while supporting 500 staff
story: WORKING from home has become the new norm for many, but for Sinead Carville she is looking forward to the day when she canto her demanding role in the office.The Loughinisland mother of three young boys is Chief Human Resources Officer for financial services company FinTrU.With just under  employees based in offices in Belfast and and the north west, Sinead oversees the companyrsquos HR . She is currently recruiting graduates for its new Belfast Academy with successful candidates getting a permanent job.While shersquos enjoying this extended period working from home and looking after her sons ndash Cillian , Ronanand four year-old Ethan ndash Sinead has ruled out this as the way forwardfor her when things s to normal after the coronavirus lockdown.ldquoWorking at home all the time is less enjoyable for me personally, I really thrive off the energy in the office and being around people on a daily basis, explained the  year-old.ldquoHistorically, I would have tried to work every Monday from home. I liked the balance of having the occasional day at home and the rest of the week in the office.ldquoI think the boys are definitely happy at having mummy home all the time and we all are enjoying that but they miss their school friends. What helps is that we still have the same routine at home. We all get up and get washed and dressed at the same time we would usually do.Sinead decided to work from home as soon as she learnt that the government was advising elderly people to shelter at home for  weeks.Her in-laws look after her and her husband Hughrsquos children after they finish school in Loughinisland.ldquoWe took the boys out of school a week earlier than their school closed because we saw what way things were going. I didnrsquot want my parents-in-law to continue to look after the boys as they are in the at-risk bracket and it just didnrsquot sit right for us, she explained.FinTrUrsquos Executive Committee decided quite early on that employees would need to continue to work in order for the company to maintain its services to Tier  investment banks across the globe and began to rent laptops and other technology to allow them to do everything they would need to do in the office mdash but at home.Sinead continued: ldquoBefore this, we didnrsquot have many people working remotely, everyone was pretty much office based. We went from that point to less than a month later when everyone was fully working from home and set up to work the same way as they can do from the office.ldquoAll our client services have been maintained over the past few weeks. There has been no disruption to our clients whatsoever which means that we can continue to do business and generate revenue.Sinead said the boys are getting used to doing their school work at home but are missing the school routine and their friends.She added: ldquoThis week the boys have got used to this new world we are all now in. Whatrsquos important is that work colleagues are in the same position sothe children do come up behind me in a video call, the guys on the other end are totally understanding as they are experiencing the same challenges.ldquoIrsquom fortunate to work for an employer who understands that we have to be adaptable and flexible as we are trying to home-school and be parent and work all at the same time.Sinead said the recent spell of good weather has been a blessing as her sons are happy to play outside by themselves in the garden.ldquoI try and get as much done as I can during the day so I can clock off to make dinner and spend some time with the children, get them out into the fresh air and do some schoolwork with them where possible, said explained.ldquoWith regards to schoolwork, I probably put myself under pressure for the first week but Irsquove relaxed more as Irsquom not a teacher theyrsquore doing well and Irsquom a busy working mummy. We do the schoolwork and the boys are getting used to school work away from the classroom.ldquoThe school is sending lots of really good material for the boys to do through dferent apps and programs and they have been very user-friendly.While she is working to ensure that her sons are sheltered from knowing just how critical the situation is outside, Sinead realises that they have taken in the changes.ldquoWe went to a supermarket for me to get groceries and they noticed that nearly all the other shops were closed, the car park was nearly empty and I had to queue alone to get in.ldquoThey understood that the world was dferent.Sinead believes that a new era of flexibility, particularly when conducting interviews with candidates over video conferencing may stick with her company when the lockdown is over.She added: ldquoI think we are learning in our organisation is that how effectively you can work from home. Maybe when we go back to normal, we might want to implement more of this blended and flexible approach in some areas of the business..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle children bringing joy to nursing home residents
story: NEWCASTLErsquoS children have answered the call to cheer up residents of Slieve Dhu Residential and Nursing Home with dozens of paintings, drawings and poems.The home on the Bryansford Road received the work of local children after manager Aimee Estrada called for some local works of art to keep up the spirits of residents during the coronavirus lockdown.Her Facebook request showed the people do care about the elderly as it reached over , people and was shared nearly  times online, prompting the encouraging response whichdelighted residents and staff alike.Ms Estrada said: ldquoWe have received lovely paintings, drawings, letters and even a piano recital from one  year-old which is just amazing.ldquoIn such uncertain times we would like to recognise the great work our staff at Slieve Dhu with providing to all our lovely residents.ldquoAt a time where they are unable to hug their loved ones, the staff and our local community are coming together to lt spirits and help them to keep smiling..prettyPhoto

title: Portaferry’s Ryan has hopes on Cupid lifting him to music heights
story: PORTAFERRY singer songwriter Ryan McMullan has just released a new four-track EP.The up and coming star, who has supported Ed Sheeran and Snow Patrol, is hoping that Ruthless Cupid will satisfy his growing legions of fans while he still works on his much anticipated debut album.The  year-old told the Recorder this week: ldquoThis is something that I really wanted to do and get it out. Itrsquos a concept EP where Irsquove made Cupid the villain rather than the hero as we all seem to do.ldquoI didnrsquot want to wait until the album is ready mdash that will be ready when itrsquos ready mdash so I thought there was no better time than the present.The former St Patrickrsquos Grammar School student, who captained the schoolrsquos hurling team, has had a short but meteoric rise to fame since he decided not to pursue a career as a civil engineer.With the success of his single, Rebellion, and Make A Mark, a collaboration with Irish folk band Beoga, he has toured non-stop, playing to sold-out shows in Dublin and Belfast as well as support slots with The Coronas on their Long Way Home tour. Last year he opened the Acoustic stage at the Glastonbury Festival.He also opened for Snow Patrol in the US, Europe and Asia and stood in as an honorary member of the band when guitarist Johnny McDaid was recovering after surgery.The son of Nuala and John McMullan, who still in Portaferry, Ryan started off performing at a young age, singing in a local band, Purple Road, when he was in his mid-teens.He is now staying at his Belfast home, having made it back from the US last month, just two days before the country closed off its airports.Many of his concerts have had to be postponed, including two nights at the Portico Theatre in Portaferry, now rescheduled to June -, and hisUK and Ireland tour this month. He had also been due to headline his first festival, Vearsai in Donegal, last weekend.Ryanrsquos current single, In A Heartbeat, is on the new EP along with Ruthless Cupid, Some Kind of Perfect and Outcry.He explained: ldquoThese songs reflect a handful of times where it felt like Cupid has been toying with me. Amusing himself by throwing me into situations where Irsquom either out of my depth, hoping for reconciliation, or unable to escape the truth that even at theend, Irsquom still holding on to even the worst of my attempts at love.ldquoIn A Heartbeat was written to sum up a stage I think we all kind of go through sooner or later: the understanding that something that once was, is now no more.But even at the end knowing it still has a hold on you, so much so, that no matter how toxic it is, or how little sense it made, yoursquod still run back to it in a desperate attempt to salvage it.The new single is already going down well with fans as the video has been viewed over , times online.Ryan added: ldquoEverything has been going great for me so far, even without my debut album coming out and that. I donrsquot think that all these tracks will be on my new album when I feel that itrsquos ready to be released. It wouldnrsquot be new music then and I would feel that it would be a disservice to all of the fans who have supported me.ldquoRegarding the album, I wonrsquot know itrsquos finished until I listen back to it and feel that all the songs are right for it. But I can tell you that Irsquom still working away in my wee studio at home.Ruthless Cupid, is available now on all major streaming  such as Spoty, Apple and Amazon..prettyPhoto

title: Province’s top nursing chief in praise during ‘challenging times’
story: NORTHERN Irelandrsquos most senior nurse has thanked her colleagues for their dedication and professionalism at what she described as an ldquoextremely challenging time.In an open letter to staff mdash including those at the helm of the COVID- assessment centre at the Downe Hospital in Downpatrick mdash chief nursing officer Charlotte McArdle thanked nurses, midwives and nursing and midwery students for the key role they are playing, acknowledging the impact the virus is having on everyone.Mrs McArdle says she is ldquoproud of how the nursing and midwery professions have met the COVID- emergency response, ldquodemonstrating positivity and courage across the wide range of practice and service areas.She said the professionalism of staff and their contribution had never been more vital or more valued by those serving at the highest level of government, their colleagues and, most importantly, the patients, families and communities for whom they provide care and services.Mrs McArdle said the applause that has been ringing out from doorsteps across Northern Ireland on Thursday nights shows how much the whole community values the work of nurses and midwives and the faith people have in each of them.The chief nurse said that faith was well placed.Her letter continues: ldquoIt is clear that the emergency response to this pandemic requires additional people to support the health and social care workforce who are working under unprecedented pressure.ldquoTo address this issue, the Nursing and Midwery Councilhas established the COVID- temporary register. This has enabled us to expand the nursing and midwery workforce by reaching out to those who have retired or lapsed their registration over the past number of years and provided opportunities for early registration for overseas staff.ldquoI am exceptionally grateful for the excellent response demonstrated by those who have volunteered toto practice and support the professional response to this pandemic.ldquoEach and every new registrant on the emergency register is a very welcome addition to the professional team and the support you will provide will have a signicant impact on outcomes for patients and the multidisciplinary workforce.Mrs McArdle said she wanted to specically thank nursing and midwery students for their ldquovaluable contribution to the delivery of safe, person-centred care as members of the nursing and midwery team.ldquoI recognise that this is an uncertain time causing great anxiety for many of you and your families. The NMC have revised pre-registration programmes and provided students with options to undertake clinical placements in an attempt to expand the nursing and midwery workforce. This approach enables students to continue their educational programme whilst contributing to clinical services during the pandemic. ldquoThe chief nurse also acknowledged the concerns raised over the issue of personal protective equipmentover the past number of weeks, insisting that the safety of frontline staff is of the utmost importance.She said ldquoconcrete action was being taken to ensure the supply of PPE and the safe use of the equipment for all staff caring for patients during the COVID- pandemic.Mrs McArdle said no matter where nurses and midwives are providing care, the use of appropriate PPE must be prioritised.She added: ldquoWhat we are currently experiencing is unprecedented and extraordinarily dficult for everyone. I believe it is important to openly acknowledge that many of us, as nurses and midwives, are frightened and uncertain regarding the impending challenges presented by the COVID- pandemic.ldquoIn order to meet these challenges, as professionals we will need to adopt a flexible approach. This includes asking staff to work in unfamiliar settings, in dferent clinical roles or undertake a task focussed approach to provision of care. We all have a leadership responsibility to make it easy for staff to do the right thing..prettyPhoto

title: Queen Karen Europe’s best
story: A KILLYLEAGH grandmother is a European powerlting champion at the age of .Karen Burns won the European title in France in March and set a new world record in the process.Powerlting involves three disciplines mdash squat, bench press and deadlt mdash and Karen capped a brilliant performance with a world record breaking lt of  kilos in the deadlt.Itrsquos a fantastic achievement for Karen, who only took up powerlting four years ago.The legal secretary, who has two daughters and four grandchildren, started gym classes at the age of , but within a few months made the switch to powerlting.Coached by Aaron Kelly, from Affinity Fit at the CG Fitness gym in Annacloy, she trained four times a week and was soon competing and winning medals at a national, international and world levels.She was the British champion two years running in  and . She was selected for Team GBR and last year finished second in the IPF world championships in Sweden.Karen says the journey to her European title and new world record began two years ago.ldquoMany people just see the training and programme side of things, but there is a lot more under the surface, she explained.ldquoDue to starting the sport later in le and competing against lters with -plus years under their belts I had to go to every extreme to give my progression every possible advantage.ldquoAll my food was tracked and measured. My diet is nutrient dense but I can still enjoy what I eat.ldquoWater intake was tracked, daily activity was tracked, recovery was tracked, which even included a curfew mdash my coach would literally check my fit bit data to seeI had gone to bed on time.ldquoI had to darken my room completely and remove the TV to improve sleep quality. Supplements, stretching, and home work-outs to improve mobility and prevent injury were all pieces of the puzzle.Owing to the coronavirus lockdown, Karen currently canrsquot get to the gym in Annacloy, but thatrsquos not stopping her training regime.She has set up a gym at her home in Killyleagh and is continuing her preparations for this yearrsquos world championships mdash they were due to take place in Sun City, South Africa, at the end of the month, but have been postponed. She hopes they will now take place some time later in the year.She said: ldquoI love this sport and my goals going forward are to continue to challenge myself and grow as a lter, but also to motivate and inspire others to enjoy heavy lting at any level, eventhey donrsquot want to compete.ldquoI want to help break the stigma that heavy lting makes you big and bulky and show others that at  Irsquom the fittest and strongest Irsquove been in my entire le, both physically and mentally..prettyPhoto

title: Racing in lockdown but great memories live on
story: THE remainder of the spring point-to-point season has been cancelled, which means that the only fixtures to take place were East Downrsquos two meetings at Tyrella, the first North Down meeting at Kirkistown, and despite very wet conditions the Armagh meeting at Farmacaffley. This is the first time this has happened since the foot and mouth outbreak in .There is a possibility of point-to-point bumpers on racecourses when jump racing s and also an expanded autumn season.The national hunt season has ended which means no Irish Grand National on Easter Monday and no Punchestown Festival mdash Irelandrsquos Cheltenham mdash at the end of the month.Gordon Elliott, who had two winners at the recent Downpatrick meeting and who had  horses in training, is now down to , so he has had to cut back on staff.The end of the point-to-point season is a severe blow to local trainers like Paddy Turley, Stuart Crawford, Colin McKeever and Warren Ewing, who produce young horses to sell after running them in four year-old races.I understand that Co Wexford trainer Donnchadh Doyle had  four year-olds ready to make their debuts and there are a lot more trainers in the same boat.When racing resumes it will be all flat racing for a month, so with Downpatrick now only running jump racing it will be some time until locals get back to their favourite venue.With the English jump season also curtailed it is good to know that Newtownhamilton native Brian Hughes, who rode his first ever winner as a flat apprentice for his boss Kevin Prendergast at Downpatrick, has been crownedchampion jockey for the first time, with a total of  wins,  clear of reigning champion Richard Johnston.Sadly this weekrsquos news has seen thousands of horses taken out of training.With the English national hunt season coming to a close earlier than originally planned, itrsquos well done to Ballee native David Maxwell on riding a total of  winners from a total of only  rides. He rides all his own horses.It was also a very good season for another Downpatrick rider, Danny McMenamin, who is attached to the yard of Nicky Richards, for whom Tony Dobbin was stable jockey for many years.Danny, who gets plenty of rides for other yards, rode a fantastic  winners from  rides. He also rode many to finish either second or third during the season.The original fixture list for  is now null and void so the original dates for Downpatrick and Down Royal, when we hopefully get back to normal sooner than later, will be all change to those originally sent out to members.An interesting fact that I learned with interest at the weekend was that Willie Robinson, who rode Laffy to win the  Ulster National at Downpatrick for the Queen Mother, was retained by Major John Corbett of Tyrella to ride for him.This was in the s before he moved to England as stable jockey to Fulke Walwyn. O course Laffy was stabled at Major Corbettrsquos establishment prior to running in the Ulster National, being trained in England by Peter Cazalet.With no racing in Ireland or England at the present time, it is a good chance to do some reading and a book just recently published, The Story of Dundalk Stadium, is a must for local racing fans.As most people know Dundalk mdash always thought about as the third local track, despite being in Co Louth mdash holds some great memories for locals, too many to record here.A feature by Frankie Fitzsimons is most interesting and he recalls the day that his father and namesake, brother Brian and himself, all rose in the famous Sweet Afton Hunters Chase back in .Frankie senior finished fth on Royal Knight, now owned by Tom Kerr from Ballygowan, while Brian rode Satin Link, also owned by Kerr, whose colours were red with the initials THK on them. Frankie finished third on Bright Cottage in the colours of Brightrsquos Arnold Ennis, who at that stage was a farmer but later turned his farm into a popular golf club.The book records that Frankie senior won the Sweet Afton in  on Fort Wayne, trained by Major John Corbett at Tyrella. He also rode Copper Cottage, trained beside Downpatrick Racecourse by Ned Altern in . He also won the race in  on Copper Ridge, like Copper Cottage owned by Major T W Hughes, this one also trained by Ned Altern. This race was won in  by Frigid Fox, owned by S J Martin from Ballynahinch and ridden by his son Raymond.In later years this race became known as the Tallanstown Hunters Chase and was won by Bald Joker in the colours of Christine McBratney and ridden by her brother-in-law Colin, now a trainer at Crossgar.Frankie Fitzsimons junior rode a few winners under rules, but the one that he will always recall was when he rode Palo to victory in the opening hurdle race of the day at Dundalk in , the horse being owned by the well known busy draper, Downpatrickrsquos Joe Rea, and trained by Peter McGreevy.Back in  owner trainer Tom McConnell, from Carsonstown, near Saintfield, and Darragh Cross amateur Barney Jones recorded their first ever success when successful with loving star in the bumper race.Barney told me recently that on their way that day they collected a lot of bets to place on the horse and as his mouth got dry when he rode he was sucking a sweet that stuck to the roof of his mouth at the start.In  Farranfad farmer and horse breeder Brian Kennedy pulled off a   shock when he saddled Star of Venosos in his green and white belt colours to win the valuable CarrollHandicap Hurdle under Harry Rodgers, now a trainer.This was Brianrsquos first ever success as a trainer and although he only held a licence for a short time he also saddled his charge to win the Ulster Cesarewitch at   at Downpatrick when,memory serves me correctly, it was ridden by Ards jockey Philip Lowry.Lots of other names like Miss K R Payne, Leslie Crawford, Willie Rooney, Jeremy Maxwell, Sammy Shields, Robin Kidd and Pat McAteer feature in the book that brings back some great memories of a popular course, no longer the same to some of us..prettyPhoto

title: Recognition for poet Stephen
story: A BALLYGOWAN poet is celebrating after his debut anthology was recognised by two major awarding bodies.Stephen Sextonrsquos If All the World and Love Were Young was awarded the highly acclaimed American E M Forester Award which was previously won by Seamus Heaney in .His anthology, published by Penguin Books, was also shortlisted for this yearrsquos Shine Strong Award ndash an award presented annually to the author of the best first collection of poems published by an Irish poet.Stephen says his work centres on coming to terms with the death of his mother, Elizabeth, who passed away in .He said: ldquoI started writing a book of poems that initially were meant to be frivolous and entertaining.ldquoHowever, as I began writing, the intense grief I was battling at the time came to the fore.Critics say what developed was a touching tribute to his mother which they described as a moving narrative exploring bereavement, family le, memories and loss.The judging  consisted of poets Colum McCann, Jhumpa Lahiri and Paul Muldoon.As part of his prize fund for winning the highly acclaimed award, Stephen received , to travel and stay in the United States.Downpatrick poet Damian Smyth, head of literature at the Arts Council of Northern Ireland, congratulated Stephen on his award.He said: ldquoThe sense is quickly growing on both sides of the Atlantic that Stephen Sexton is already one of those rare poets whose obvious and prodigious lyrical gts are matched both by accessibility and universality.He added: ldquoIt is poignant that the person for whom the whole book is an elegy ndash his late mother mdashnever lived to see the acclaim lavished on her son.ldquoHowever, there are few contemporary works which describe the human processes of grief, loss, hurt and how love survives and endures as memorably and as movingly as this one, with virtuoso technique and profound wisdom, which I have to say is already a classic. What an achievement that is and what a poet..prettyPhoto

title: Resort quiet as public obey health advice
story: NEWCASTLE was eerily quiet over the Easter weekend with all the main car parks in the town centre closed to visitors as part of the drive to encourage people to stay at home.Police were deployed across the resort and officers were posted at several other locations to ensure people complied with the directive to only travelabsolutely necessary.Officers took up positions at the Dundrum Road entrance to the resort, at nearby Murlough and further along the coastline at Tyrella beach to ensure people adhered to public health advice to stay at home to save lives in the grip of the pandemic.Newry, Mourne and Down Council introduced a number of changes at its car parks at Downs Road, Donard Park and Castle Park in the resort to deter visitors from parking.The car parks were only open to local people who were shopping for essential supplies and local care staff, but the number of available spaces at each of the parks was limited.Ahead of the Easter weekend, council officials had asked non-residents and member of the public to stay away from Newcastle car parks and make no attempt to enter them as part of the local authorityrsquos ongoing COVID- response in line with guidance from the Public Health Agency.Mournes councillor Willie Clarke said the message to people was thatthey stayed at home this Easter they would help save lives.He said it was important that with Easter now over, people kept obeying public health advice and resisted the temptation to visit family and friends.ldquoNewcastle was quiet over Easter and that was a good thing in the current climate. Clearly the vast majority of people heeded the advice they had been given, but there were a number of issues involving young people drinking together, the councillor continued.ldquoThe lsquostay at home messagersquo has got through but there is no room for complacency. We need to keep this up and while I appreciate that it is dficult and frustrating for many to stay at home and only venture outside for essential supplies, there will be light at the end of the tunnel.Cllr Clarke said while everyonersquos focus was on doing everything they could to stay safe, he believed that the pandemic will pass.ldquoWe all have a role to play to ensure that this happens as soon as possible, he said. ldquoPeople are yearning for ato normality, but we all need to play out part to ensure that this happens.Cllr Clarke said the impact of the lockdown was having a major impact on businesses in Newcastle who rely heavily upon tourism and who are suffering as a result of the current restrictions on businesses opening.ldquoBusiness has been devastated and I hope that those who have been forced to close will be provided with all the help and support they deserve moving forward, he continued.Cllr Clarke also praised all frontline NHS workers and Newry, Mourne and Down Council staff for continuing to deliver services in the face of the pandemic.He added: ldquoWe owe these people so much. They have stepped forward to help in their own respective fields and deserve our thanks.ldquoAll NHS staff have been fantastic as have local authority directors, who are working from home, and a number of other frontline staff. Refuse collection workers who have maintained normal service levels throughout the pandemic and are to be congratulated.Police confirmed that province-wide, officers issued  fines to people who did not heed the message to stay at home to prevent the spread of coronavirus over the Easter weekend. Officers said they broke up house parties, barbecues and childrenrsquos play dates, with some gatherings of more than  people.PSNI Assistant Chief Constable Alan Todd said that up to % of people had complied with the restrictions last weekend, with a ldquosignicant deployment of officers on Easter Monday and Tuesday..prettyPhoto

title: Send off postponed for popular Academy Primary School principal
story: SAINTFIELD school principal Stephen Moore admits he has been close to tears several times over the past few weeks.The principal of Academy Primary School says he has agonised, sometimes late at night, over whether or not to keep his school open in the early weeks of the coronavirus lockdown.He also admits to feeling emotional clearing out his office ahead of his deputy, Mr Richard Fegan, officially taking over as principal from August .After nearly  years at the Listooder Road School, Mr Moore is retiring.His retirement could not have come at a more challenging time, but he leaves his school in the best of hands with his  teaching staff and  non-teaching staff.The school has been looking after the children of NHS staff and key workers since the lockdown. Itrsquos a service he says he and his staff have been proud to offer.He has pupils whose parents are key NHS medics, including a couple who are both respiratory consultants, and knows the need to provide a place of shelter and safety for children of key workers is critical.ldquoEvenI had to keep the school open for one child of an NHS worker, it would be worth it, he said. ldquoMy head has said lsquoshut the schoolrsquo like the rest of them, but my heart says we are in this together and wersquove got to do our part.ldquoHowever, Irsquom not condemning any school who has closed as they have probably done so for the best of reasons.ldquoI sat in tears on Sunday evening as I didnrsquot know what I was doing was right in keeping the school open or not. We are one of the few schools offering cover for the weekends and all over Easter. Not one of my staff refused to come in to take a turn to keep the school open.ldquoIrsquove had  or more people offering to come in and help. Irsquove a great staff and they all pull together. At the end of the day, we have done our very best to safeguard the children and staff.Thankfully, Mr Moore has not received any reports of coronavirus amongst his pupils and staff, and he hopes that this status will continue.Known for not taking himself too seriously, Mr Moore has been entertaining and educating his pupils with hilarious Facebook videos of himself as educator turned entertainer. Using his considerable wit and cuddly toys as pretend schoolchildren, the principal of  years has taught mathematics, the importance of punctuation and much more over the last few weeks.He describes the incoming principal, Mr Fegan, as ldquoalmost like a son to me, and is equally proud of his other two former vice-principals, Mr Niall Stevenson and Mrs Lorna Stitt , who left the school to become principals of Downpatrick Primary School and Portavogie Primary School respectively.Mr Moore taught in primary schools in Belfast and Lisburn after he qualying in . He came to Academy as vice-principal in September  and taught a composite P-P class.He took over as principal from Mr George Smyth just five years later. The school at that time only had  children mdash it now has  children registered with double classes in all year groups and the nursery.ldquoI was appointed acting principal and Irsquove been acting principal ever since, quips Mr Moore.ldquoThe highlights for me have been many. Itrsquos been a honour not only to see children develop and flourish, but also my staff. Irsquom delighted with how my vice principals have gone on in their careers and that Mr Fegan has now been confirmed as the incoming principal after first coming here as a student teacher.ldquoIrsquove taken as much pleasure at seeing how some of my former pupils have fared in their careers and le as much as our AQE results, which are excellent. The school has also had three outstanding inspection reports in my time and apart from perhaps three rooms, the school has been completely refurbished.ldquoThe children are great ambassadors and a lot of them go on to to Down High School or Saintfield High School or Belfast grammar schools and quite often end up as head boy or head girl.His official send-off mdash a special assembly with an eveningat Temple Golf Club on June  mdash has been postponed.ldquoPersonally, itrsquos not ideal but there are people losing their lives, incomes, jobs, business are crashing, doctors and nurses putting their lives on the line, I will come back at a later stage and there will be a chance for everyone to say goodbye,said Mr Moore.ldquoTo be honest, Irsquom more upset for the Ps as most of them have been with us for eight years. Wersquove had to cancel going to Edinburgh, their leaving show which was going to be The Lion King in my honour.He said that his greatest delight at the school has been his pupils.ldquoThey are the main reason for my y tenure. It has been a joy to be their principal, he added.ldquoIt has also been an honour to have worked alongside the board of governors, both past and present, who have shared my vision for the school and supported me in its realisation.ldquoI am indebted in particular to the late Rev Alan Delamere, Mr David Donnan, Mr Geoffrey Perrin and currently Mr Peter Shaw for their leadership at the helm.ldquoThe current members of our teaching and non-teaching staff continue to reflect the professional dedication and loving care of their predecessors. I have been truly blessed to have a staff who have had a collective desire to put children first.Mr Moore also paid tribute to the parents and s for their ldquodaily partnership with the staff and your personal support to me as principal for over two decades.He and his we, Lynne, who live in Saintfield, share five children together and he says retirement will bring him a chance for them both to travel ndash when the travel ban is lted ndash and for him to devote more time to his beloved sports mdash hersquos a major football and rugby fan.He has been approached to do some educational consultancy work when he is officially retired but is happy to limit that to just several days a week.Mr Moore added: ldquoI can honestly say that during my time at Academy I have never wished that I had been a school leader anywhere  or that I was employed in an alternative profession.ldquoI will definitely shed a tear or two when I go. They will get over me, of course, as nobody is irreplaceable, but I will certainly miss the children and staff. I will not miss the responsibility of the day to day running of the place, but Irsquom a social animal and I will really miss everyone..prettyPhoto

title: The legacy of John de Courcy
story: THE story starts in  when the Norman soldier-adventurer, Sir John de Courcy, went north from Dublin, the headquarters of Norman power in Ireland, and arrived at Downpatrick on February .De Courcy was a man of great physical strength and size. He was also brave and daring. He now attempted to conquer all of Ulster, which King Henry II had granted to him five years before. He gathered around him about  knights and archers, who, with their attendants, made up about one thousand men.Downpatrick was the capital of the Gaelic Kingdom of Ulidia. But de Courcyrsquos men were half starved when they reached the town they stole everything that they could lay their hands upon ndash they ate and drank, plundered and killed, until half of Downpatrick was in ruin.Almost at once the Gaelic king, Mac Dunleavy, came with a large force to attack de Courcy. He went out to meet Mac Dunleavy, and chose a strategic place to make an attack. The Gaels rushed in with great bravery, but they were unable to break the ranks of the Normans and after a fierce fight they were repulsed with great loss.But the Ulidians put up a most determined resistance. The valiant de Courcy attacked the Gaels as many as three times that year. De Courcy then suffered a number of reverses, so that it was an effort to hold his ground.He was defeated near Newry with the loss of  men and was intercepted in one of his many raids by the Dalaradian king, Cumee OrsquoFlynn. He escaped from the battlefield with only eleven companions and having lost their horses they fled on foot for two days and two nights, closely pursued, without food or sleep.But in other battles de Courcy was victorious, so that as the year passed his position in Ulster was strengthened. Now he started to build Dundrum Castle, along with Carrickfergus at a later date. The failure of local government in Down, now prompted King Henry II to make de Courcy the justiciar mdash or viceroy mdash in Ireland. During this time Connaught was invaded, de Courcy burning and slaying after his usual fashion.He was confronted by two kings from Munster and Thomond, who had united armies. Not venturing to make battle, he retreated northwards to save himself and his forces from destruction. He arrived in Ballysadare on the Sligo coast, with the enemy pursuing closely behind. He set fire to the buildings and fled south east.As he was crossing the Curlew Hills de Courcy was overtaken by the Gaels, who fell upon his men and killed a greater number of them. It was with dficulty that he escaped to Leinster with what remained of his army.De Courcy had enemies at court, chief among them being Hugh de Lacy, who poisoned King Johnrsquos mind against him. He was proclaimed a rebel and a traitor. De Lacy, now Lord Justice, was sent to arrest him.After a number of unsuccessful attempts de Courcy was atbetrayed by some of his own servants who led him to his retreat at Downpatrick, where he was taken in . His enemies came down upon him on Good Friday when he was barefooted and unarmed, doing penance in Down Cathedral. He snatched the nearest weapon, a great wooden cross, with which he dashed out the brains of many of his attackers before he was overpowered.Between his arrival at Downpatrick in  and his expulsion in  de Courcy founded many religious establishments, built abbeys for the Benedictines and the Cistercians and the great fortress of Dundrum Castle, then known as Rath.He had chosen a good site on a -foot high hill overlooking an inlet in Dundrum Bay in the plains of Lecale and the pass between the Mourne Mountains and the foothills of Slieve Croob.It is not known when the main keep was built, but it was a remarkable achievement in military science and architecture by the knights who had come back from the Holy Land on crusade. The diameter of the keep is  feet, and it is  feet high.But as a result of trouble in Downpatrick, de Courcy lost control of Dundrum Castle along with Carrickfergus Castle in Co Antrim. In the year after his expulsion de Courcy tried to recapture Dundrum Castle, now held by his father-in-law, the King of the Isle of Man. De Courcyrsquos attempts ended in failure and the castle became crown property. In  it was visited by King John.Dundrum Castle consisted of two storeys with wooden floors above the basement, and the original entrance on the ground floor. Chambers and passages were constructed along with a staircase rising to the walk wall.For over two centuries from  the history of the castle is barely documented. It appears that the Magennises seized Dundrum sometime in the th century and held it intermittently until it was surrendered to the Crown by Phelim Magennis in . The Savages appear to have been the owners when the Earl of Kildare took it in .The castle was granted to Lord Cromwell in , then sold in  by his grandson, the first earl of Ardglass, to Sir Francis Blundell.During the rising of  the Magennises retrieved the castle, but it was recaptured by the Parliamentarians, who partly demolished it in . By  the castle and grounds were placed into state care.Perhaps more than anywhere  in Ireland, Dundrum reflects the Anglo-Irish spirit ndash the work of the great de Courcy, the soldier-knight adventurer. Today Dundrum Castle is a ruin. De Courcyrsquos other achievement in Ulster, Carrickfergus Castle, is the best preserved Norman castle in Ireland..prettyPhoto

title: When Stirling Moss came to Downpatrick
story: A RETIRED Downpatrick motor dealer has expressed his ldquotremendous sadness at the death of Sir Stirling Moss at the weekend.The motor racing legend, who was , was the guest of honour at the opening of Mr Billy McCormickrsquos refurbished Black and White garage in .It was a major event in the town and there were hundreds of people outside the newly renovated premises in Church Street, all eager to get a glimpse of one of the worldrsquos top sports stars.Mr McCormick has fond memories of the occasion. ldquoIt was a big day in every sense. Stirling Moss was a world renowned motor ace and here he was in Downpatrick.ldquoThere was a big crowd and lots of dignitaries who all wanted to see him.Mossrsquos motor racing career had ended four years earlier at the age of  after a horric crash which left him in a coma for a month. Even so, he is regarded as one of the greatest drivers of all time, despite not being world championThe winner of  Formula One grands prix, he finished runner-up in the world championship four times and finished third on three other occasions. He also competed outside Formula One and won a total of  of the  races he entered in his career.His trip to Downpatrick had been organised by the BP oil company, with which he was closely related at the time.Mr McCormick said he was slightly taken aback when he met his distinguished guest for the first time.ldquoI greeted him when he arrived at the entrance and the first thing he said to me was where was the loo. He needed to go to the toilet, Mr McCormick recalled.ldquoHe was absolutely brilliant and extremely down to earth. This man was an absolute hero to all of the people there and he could not have been nicer.Mr McCormick said it was a ldquomemorable day for all concerned and that Moss joined them afterwards for a party in the Dunmore Hotel in Killyleagh.He added: ldquoI am extremely sad that he has passed away. I followed his career with great interest..prettyPhoto
